Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Engineer: Exploration of Roles and Tools to Fulfill Diverse Researcher Needs in Collaborative Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a need to transform supercomputer and other cyberinfrastructure (CI) resource provisioning procedures and practices on campuses with federated, hybrid cloud services handled by specialized expertise of a CI Engineer. The CI Engineer complements campus system/network engineering personnel, and leads the seamless orchestration of provisioning local and remote resources (e.g., cyber-enabled scientific instruments, public clouds) to meet data-intensive research and education needs of faculty and students.

This project investigates roles, tools and policies that enable the viability and sustainability of the CI Engineer position. More than just exploration, the project involves several pilot experiments with domain-application workflows. The experiments consider connectivity and communication procedures necessary for transitioning interdisciplinary collaborations from experimental environments to production systems. To automate the provisioning of application-specific resources, custom templates are being developed for diverse data-intensive (web-based) applications. The custom templates abstract the high-level policy and performance throughput requirements of data-intensive applications, and personalize them to lower-level control specifications implementable in an on-demand manner by virtualization technologies such as OpenStack and OpenFlow. Lastly, case studies, best practices and open-source software applications are to be generated to foster hybrid cloud service models in research and education, while avoiding many layers of co-ordination. Significant attention is being paid to broadening participation of underrepresented groups, and to the CI Engineer interaction with peer communities that are addressing challenges of next-generation campus cyberinfrastructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The traditional model of a central supercomputer resource serving a majority of on-campus users' needs is being challenged. Especially in interdisciplinary and data-intensive fields such as bioinformatics, or geoscience - data storage/processing facilities, expert collaborators and specialized compute resources do not always reside within campus boundaries. There is a need to transform supercomputer and other cyberinfrastructure (CI) resource provisioning procedures and practices on campuses with federated, hybrid cloud services handled by specialized expertise of a CI Engineer. This project investigated the roles and tools needed by a CI Engineer to fulfill diverse research and education needs in collaborative environments of data-intensive science applications.

 

The project involved several pilot experiments with domain-application workflows and considered connectivity and communication procedures. Thus, results provided insights necessary for transitioning interdisciplinary collaborations from experimental environments to production systems. Novel 'custom templates' for diverse data-intensive (web-based) applications were developed. The custom templates abstract the high-level policy and performance throughput requirements of data-intensive applications, and 'personalize' them to lower-level control specifications implementable in an on-demand manner by virtualization technologies. In addition, project team assessed how next-generation CI user service models with custom templates can be composed by campus IT staff and particularly by the CI Engineer. Thus, this project created best practices to sustainably support hybrid cloud use cases in research and education, while avoiding many layers of co-ordination.

 

The project has seen the MU CI Engineer role take shape in many impactful ways. CI Engineers worked closely with graduate students and had access to cyberinfrastructure resources at MU and at the national level (e.g., CyVerse, Neuroscience Gateway, JetStream, GENI/CloudLab). They worked closely with data-intensive application user groups to help them adopt hybrid cloud services to scale and secure their research and education workflows. A major accomplishment of this project is that a CI Engineer position has been setup in the College of Engineering as a permanent on-going position at MU, and the Campus Research Computing Support Services group has currently hired CI Engineers and is looking to hire several more to coordinate campus-wide needs in various disciplines.

 

The project team conducted detailed studies of several Science DMZ projects, and have co-authored a Book Chapter that outlines best practices for CI Engineering to support domain applications. The results of this study are published in the form of a Book Chapter in a 'Big Data Networking' book published by CRC Press in 2015, and also has been shared with the broader community in several conference, workshop and other meeting venues.

 

Project team collected system and network measurements, as well as user experience surveys (i.e., subjective assessments) pertaining to productive use of MU Science DMZ, HPC, CyVerse, Neuroscience Gateway and GENI/CloudLab resources. Through such a collection, the team worked to document and disseminate valuable real-world data sets that provide understanding of workload profiles for diverse applications/user-groups. Further, the project team utilized the data sets in the development of software frameworks and tools to help CI Engineer in allocation and management of resources. The project thus overall improved performance, increased scalability, and cost-effectiveness for diverse use cases in bioinformatics, health science, geoscience, imaging and community-support programs including education.
